model.dek: All you're missing is the red checkered tablecloth.
model.promoDek: All you're missing is the red checkered tablecloth.
model.seoDescription: These classic pasta recipes include spaghetti, carbonara, and pesto.
model.socialDescription: Ain't no school like old school.

items.caption: Bucatini and penne are the traditional shapes for this simple pork and tomato sauce. Use guanciale, the pork jowl, for getting the rich and classic flavor.
You don't get much simpler (or delicious) than cacio e pepe. The cheese choice takes this from simple to sublime. Using Grana Padano and Pecorino takes this pasta beyond the basics.
Pasta and pork. Once you plop on a poached egg, you've entered the pasta hall of fame. And it is very hallowed, delicious ground.
You're slow-simmering this pasta sauce, just like grandma and all of the grandmas before her did. Use a three meat combination to make these meatballs taste just like her sauce.
Roasting the tomatoes makes more out of canned tomatoes; adding butter balances out the acidity in this textbook-perfect tomato sauce.
Pasta with tomatoes and mozzarella transcends time (and even temperature). Serve this dish hot or even at room temperature.
A baked ziti is all about the meat. Use braised pork shoulder, spicy Italian sausage, and pancetta to amp up the tomato sauce and sprinkle on dried crushed red pepper for some heat.
Stop. Clam and pasta time. Spaghetti alla vongole, the fancy name for this garlic-rich pasta, gets its briny sauce from the clams' juice.

Lasagna is the greatest casserole of all time. Between each of these saucy and gooey layers, you'll see what we're talking about. What makes this even better? These noodles are no-boil, saving you some time.
Usually classic pastas call long-simmered sauces and hand-rolling shapes to mind. Not anymore. This super fast shrimp scampi could work just as well on weeknights as for a big gathering.
There's history at work when beef and aromatic vegetables slowly cook down with wine, tomato paste, and broth. It wouldn't be so bad if this history repeated itself, right?

nextGallery.hed: The Greatest Pastas of All Time
nextGallery.dek: You don't mess with a classic.
nextGallery.promoDek: You don't mess with a classic.
nextGallery.promoHed: The Greatest Pastas of All Time

items.caption: We think rigatoni is a winner in this meaty ragu sauce, but any short, tubular pasta will work.
This weeknight classic gets a dose of slow-simmered and robust sauce. Use three meats (beef, veal, and pork) to form the centerpiece meatballs.
A plate of orecchiette ("little ear") pasta is like a plateful of little cups. Here, they cup up the kale and breadcrumbs.
How do you make our favorite lasagna? With just the right mix of hearty sausage, vibrant spinach, and a perfectly balanced three-cheese blend. No-boil noodles are a no-brainer.
Broiled pasta > baked pasta. Top this penne and sausage with mozzarella to get that bubbly melted cheese everyone loves, minus a lot of oven time.
Topping this pasta with a yolk that firms up from the heat of the dish is the winning move here.
Cook capellini in Parmesan brothit'll absorb the rich umami flavor while it soaks up the excess liquid.
Contrast thick pappardelle with toppings like prosciutto, arugula, and savory leeks.
Cacio e pepe (cheese and pepper) is the most rudimentary of all classic pastas. How to make it taste elegant? Use the right kind of cheeseGrana Padano and Pecorinoand lots of cranks of black pepper.
Butter. Garlic. Shrimp. Sometimes, that's all you really need.
With a smoky and nutty undertone, this almond-tomato pesto takes a classic flavor combination and changes it up.
Even though pasta carbonara seems simple, it requires practice; don't make it for company till you've figured out the timing for everything.
Genius pasta rule: don't throw out the cooking water. This rigatoni's guanciale and Pecorino are both very saltyusing the pasta water tempers the dish.
Maltagliati is classically messytopped with favas, sausage, and tomatoesit's crazy good.

nextGallery.seoDescription: These classic pasta recipes are that way for a reason.
nextGallery.socialDescription: Consider these pasta recipes part of a classical education.

items.dek:
Named for Amatrice, a town
northeast of Rome, this pasta is traditionally
served with a long noodle like bucatini, but
we like how shorter penne captures the
spicy, meaty bits of sauce inside the tube.

items.dek:
If one pasta dish exemplifies the complexity of pan sauce precision, it's cacio e pepe (literally, cheese and pepper). The minimalist recipe calls
for only a few ingredients and doesn't even include garlic. But the techniques outlined here elevate the dish to something magnificent. The creamy twirl of noodles is like a stripped-down mac and cheeseonly more elegant and easier to make. No wonder it's on the menus of America's most stylish Italian restaurants. It's a simple standard by which cooks are measured, yet no two chefs agree on how to do it right. We sorted through the variations and found it works best with a mix of Grana Padano (velvety) and Pecorino (sharp) cheeses, and freshly cracked black pepper (you should taste the heat).
items.promoDek: The minimalist recipe calls for only a few ingredients and doesn't even include garlic. But the techniques outlined here elevate the dish to something magnificent. The creamy twirl of noodles is like a stripped-down mac and cheese only more elegant and easier to make.

items.hed: Peppery Pasta Carbonara with Poached Egg
items.promoHed: Peppery Pasta Carbonara with Poached Egg
items.socialTitle: Peppery Pasta Carbonara with Poached Egg
items.socialDescription: Peppery Pasta Carbonara with Poached Egg
items.dek:
Pasta and porkwhat's not to love? Spaghetti alla carbonara traditionally calls for  guanciale  (cured pork jowl), but bacon is weeknight-friendly and every bit as satisfying. Raw egg is typically mixed into the hot pasta, but a poached egg on top feels 
more substantial while still providing the requisite creaminess.

items.dek:
The briny juices from the clams help to flavor
this brothy sauce&151;the fresher the clams,
the better the dish. Clams' salinity varies
depending on their variety and provenance,
so in this case, be sure to salt the pasta
cooking water lightly.

items.dek: This perennial favorite has just the right mix of hearty sausage, vibrant spinach, and a perfectly balanced three-cheese blend. With a quick-cooking sauce and no-fuss, no-boil noodles, the assembly is easy, and one pan feeds a large crowd.
items.promoDek: This lasagna has just the right mix of hearty sausage, vibrant spinach, and a perfectly balanced three-cheese blend.
